articles.title: Spanish Word Order Guide for Couples
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Understanding Spanish word order is essential for building natural-sounding sentences. While Spanish shares some similarities with English, there are key differences that every couple learning together should master. The good news? Spanish word order is often more flexible than English, giving you creative freedom in how you express yourself.

Learning these patterns together will help you both sound more natural and confident in your Spanish conversations.

## Basic Spanish Sentence Structure

### Subject-Verb-Object (SVO)

Like English, Spanish typically follows the Subject-Verb-Object pattern for basic sentences:

| Position | Spanish | English |
|----------|---------|---------|
| Subject | Yo | I |
| Verb | amo | love |
| Object | a mi pareja | my partner |

**Full sentence:** "Yo amo a mi pareja" (I love my partner)

<VocabCard
  word="la estructura"
  translation="the structure"
  pronunciation="[lah ehs-trook-TOO-rah]"
  example="La estructura de la oraciÃ³n es importante."
/>

### The Flexibility of Spanish

Unlike English, Spanish allows more flexibility because verb conjugations already indicate the subject:

- "Yo como pizza" = "Como pizza" (I eat pizza)
- "TÃº hablas espaÃ±ol" = "Hablas espaÃ±ol" (You speak Spanish)

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Te quiero mucho"
  translation="I love you very much"
  pronunciation="[teh kee-EH-roh MOO-choh]"
  context="Notice: the subject 'yo' is implied by the verb conjugation"
/>

## Key Differences from English

### 1. Adjectives After Nouns

In Spanish, most adjectives come AFTER the noun they describe:

| English | Spanish |
|---------|---------|
| A beautiful woman | Una mujer hermosa |
| The red car | El carro rojo |
| A romantic dinner | Una cena romÃ¡ntica |
| My wonderful partner | Mi pareja maravillosa |

<VocabCard
  word="hermoso/hermosa"
  translation="beautiful"
  pronunciation="[ehr-MOH-soh / ehr-MOH-sah]"
  example="Tienes una sonrisa hermosa."
/>

### Exceptions: Adjectives Before Nouns

Some common adjectives typically go BEFORE the noun:

| Adjective | Position | Example |
|-----------|----------|---------|
| bueno/a (good) | before | un buen dÃ­a |
| malo/a (bad) | before | una mala idea |
| grande (great/big) | before | un gran amor |
| pequeÃ±o/a (small) | either | una pequeÃ±a casa |
| primero/a (first) | before | el primer beso |

**Note:** "Grande" becomes "gran" before singular nouns and means "great" rather than "big."

<CultureTip title="Meaning Changes with Position" flag="ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸">
Some adjectives change meaning based on position! "Un hombre grande" (a big man) vs "un gran hombre" (a great man). "Mi viejo amigo" (my long-time friend) vs "mi amigo viejo" (my elderly friend). This adds poetic depth to Spanish expression.
</CultureTip>

### 2. Negation Placement

In Spanish, "no" comes directly before the verb:

| English | Spanish |
|---------|---------|
| I don't understand | No entiendo |
| She doesn't speak English | Ella no habla inglÃ©s |
| We don't want to go | No queremos ir |

### 3. Question Word Order

Spanish questions often keep the same word order as statements, just with question marks and intonation:

| Statement | Question |
|-----------|----------|
| TÃº hablas espaÃ±ol. | Â¿TÃº hablas espaÃ±ol? |
| Ella viene maÃ±ana. | Â¿Ella viene maÃ±ana? |

Or with inverted order (verb before subject):

| Question | Translation |
|----------|-------------|
| Â¿Hablas tÃº espaÃ±ol? | Do you speak Spanish? |
| Â¿Viene ella maÃ±ana? | Is she coming tomorrow? |

## Object Pronouns: A Key Difference

### Direct and Indirect Object Pronouns Go BEFORE the Verb

| English | Spanish |
|---------|---------|
| I love you | Te amo |
| She calls me | Ella me llama |
| I give it to you | Te lo doy |
| He tells us | Ã‰l nos dice |

<VocabCard
  word="te"
  translation="you (object pronoun)"
  pronunciation="[teh]"
  example="Te extraÃ±o mucho."
/>

### Object Pronoun Chart

| Pronoun | Meaning | Example |
|---------|---------|---------|
| me | me | Me quieres (You love me) |
| te | you | Te veo (I see you) |
| lo/la | him/her/it | Lo conozco (I know him) |
| nos | us | Nos aman (They love us) |
| os | you all | Os extraÃ±o (I miss you all) |
| los/las | them | Las invito (I invite them) |

### Double Object Pronouns

When you have both indirect and direct objects, indirect comes first:

- "Te lo doy" (I give it to you) - te (indirect) + lo (direct)
- "Me la compras" (You buy it for me) - me (indirect) + la (direct)

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Te lo prometo"
  translation="I promise it to you"
  pronunciation="[teh loh proh-MEH-toh]"
  context="Indirect pronoun 'te' + direct pronoun 'lo' before the verb"
/>

## Adverb Placement

### General Rule: Near the Verb

Adverbs typically go near the verb they modify, often immediately after:

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| Hablo espaÃ±ol bien | I speak Spanish well |
| Camina lentamente | He/She walks slowly |
| Come rÃ¡pidamente | He/She eats quickly |

### Time Adverbs: Flexible

Time adverbs can go at the beginning or end of sentences:

| Position | Spanish | English |
|----------|---------|---------|
| Beginning | MaÃ±ana vamos al cine | Tomorrow we're going to the movies |
| End | Vamos al cine maÃ±ana | We're going to the movies tomorrow |

<VocabCard
  word="siempre"
  translation="always"
  pronunciation="[see-EHM-preh]"
  example="Siempre te amarÃ©."
/>

### Common Adverbs for Couples

| Spanish | English | Example |
|---------|---------|---------|
| siempre | always | Siempre pienso en ti |
| nunca | never | Nunca te olvidarÃ© |
| tambiÃ©n | also | Yo tambiÃ©n te quiero |
| muy | very | Eres muy especial |
| mucho | a lot | Te extraÃ±o mucho |
| juntos | together | Vamos juntos |

## Practicing Word Order Together

### Exercise 1: Rearrange to Spanish Order

Transform these English sentences to Spanish word order:

1. "The romantic dinner" â†’ "La cena romÃ¡ntica"
2. "I love you" â†’ "Te amo"
3. "She doesn't understand" â†’ "Ella no entiende"
4. "My beautiful wife" â†’ "Mi esposa hermosa"

### Exercise 2: Build Sentences Together

Take turns building sentences with these elements:

**Elements:** yo / amar / tÃº / mucho
**Answer:** "Yo te amo mucho" or "Te amo mucho"

**Elements:** nosotros / querer / viajar / juntos
**Answer:** "Nosotros queremos viajar juntos" or "Queremos viajar juntos"

### Exercise 3: Adjective Placement Practice

Describe each other using adjectives after nouns:
- "Tienes ojos bonitos" (You have pretty eyes)
- "Eres una persona increÃ­ble" (You're an incredible person)
- "Tienes una sonrisa hermosa" (You have a beautiful smile)

<CultureTip title="Poetic Freedom in Spanish" flag="ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸">
Spanish poets and songwriters often play with word order for emphasis and rhythm. "Amor te tengo" (Love I have for you) is grammatically correct though unusual, creating poetic emphasis. As you advance, you'll appreciate this creative flexibility.
</CultureTip>

## Common Word Order Patterns

### Expressing Likes with "Gustar"

The verb "gustar" (to please/like) has a special structure:

| Spanish | Literal | Natural English |
|---------|---------|-----------------|
| Me gusta el cafÃ© | Coffee pleases me | I like coffee |
| Te gustan las flores | Flowers please you | You like flowers |
| Nos gusta bailar | Dancing pleases us | We like to dance |

<VocabCard
  word="me gusta"
  translation="I like"
  pronunciation="[meh GOOS-tah]"
  example="Me gusta pasar tiempo contigo."
/>

### Commands (Imperatives)

In commands, object pronouns attach to the END of the verb:

| Positive Command | Translation |
|-----------------|-------------|
| Â¡BÃ©same! | Kiss me! |
| Â¡AbrÃ¡zame! | Hug me! |
| Â¡Dime! | Tell me! |
| Â¡EscÃºchame! | Listen to me! |

But negative commands keep pronouns before the verb:
- "Â¡No me olvides!" (Don't forget me!)
- "Â¡No te vayas!" (Don't go!)

### Questions with Question Words

Question words typically come at the beginning:

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| Â¿DÃ³nde vives? | Where do you live? |
| Â¿CuÃ¡ndo llegamos? | When do we arrive? |
| Â¿CÃ³mo te llamas? | What's your name? |
| Â¿Por quÃ© me amas? | Why do you love me? |
| Â¿QuÃ© quieres hacer? | What do you want to do? |

## Word Order in Complex Sentences

### Connecting Clauses

| Connector | Example |
|-----------|---------|
| que (that) | SÃ© que me quieres |
| porque (because) | Te llamo porque te extraÃ±o |
| cuando (when) | SonrÃ­o cuando te veo |
| si (if) | SerÃ© feliz si vienes |

<PhraseOfDay
  word="SÃ© que me amas porque me lo demuestras"
  translation="I know you love me because you show me"
  pronunciation="[seh keh meh AH-mahs POR-keh meh loh deh-MWEHS-trahs]"
  context="Complex sentence with multiple clauses"
/>

## Tips for Natural Word Order

1. **When in doubt, follow SVO** - It works most of the time
2. **Put adjectives after nouns** - Until you learn the exceptions
3. **Object pronouns before verbs** - me, te, lo, la, nos, los, las
4. **Negation before verbs** - "no" comes right before the verb
5. **Listen to native speakers** - Music and podcasts help internalize patterns

## Practice Dialogue for Couples

**Partner A:** "Â¿DÃ³nde quieres cenar esta noche?"
(Where do you want to have dinner tonight?)

**Partner B:** "Me gustarÃ­a ir a un restaurante italiano."
(I would like to go to an Italian restaurant.)

**Partner A:** "Â¡QuÃ© buena idea! Te lo propongo: vamos al nuevo restaurante del centro."
(What a good idea! I suggest to you: let's go to the new restaurant downtown.)

**Partner B:** "Â¡Perfecto! Siempre me haces feliz."
(Perfect! You always make me happy.)

## Building Confidence Together

Understanding Spanish word order is like learning the rhythm of a dance. At first, you might step on each other's toes, but with practice, you'll move together naturally. The beauty of learning as a couple is that you can correct each other gently and celebrate progress together.

Remember: Spanish word order may feel different from English, but it follows logical patterns that become intuitive with practice. Keep talking to each other in Spanish, and soon these patterns will feel completely natural.

<CTA text="Ready to build beautiful Spanish sentences together?" buttonText="Start Learning Now" />

import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';

Dobra wiadomoÅ›Ä‡ - niemiecka wymowa jest bardziej regularna niÅ¼ angielska! Wiele dÅºwiÄ™kÃ³w jest podobnych do polskich. Oto kompletny przewodnik dla polskich par.

## SamogÅ‚oski podstawowe

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Kurze und lange Vokale"
  translation="KrÃ³tkie i dÅ‚ugie samogÅ‚oski"
  pronunciation="kur-ce unt lan-ge wo-ka-le"

/>

### SamogÅ‚oski krÃ³tkie vs dÅ‚ugie

| SamogÅ‚oska | KrÃ³tka | PrzykÅ‚ad | DÅ‚uga | PrzykÅ‚ad |
|------------|--------|----------|-------|----------|
| **a** | jak polskie "a" | w**a**s | dÅ‚uÅ¼sze "a" | T**a**g |
| **e** | jak polskie "e" | B**e**tt | jak "e" w "lewy" | g**e**ben |
| **i** | jak polskie "i" | b**i**tte | dÅ‚uÅ¼sze "i" | d**ie** |
| **o** | jak polskie "o" | k**o**mmt | dÅ‚uÅ¼sze "o" | **O**hr |
| **u** | jak polskie "u" | M**u**tter | dÅ‚uÅ¼sze "u" | g**u**t |

<CultureTip title="DÅ‚ugoÅ›Ä‡ zmienia znaczenie!" flag="ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª">
"Stadt" (miasto) vs "Staat" (paÅ„stwo) - rÃ³Å¼nica tylko w dÅ‚ugoÅ›ci "a"!
SÅ‚uchajcie uwaÅ¼nie i Ä‡wiczcie rozrÃ³Å¼nianie.
</CultureTip>

## Umlauty - a, o, u

To dÅºwiÄ™ki, ktÃ³re nie istniejÄ… w polskim!

<VocabCard
  word="a / o / u"
  translation="Umlaute - specjalne samogÅ‚oski"
  pronunciation="zaokrÄ…glone usta + odpowiedni dÅºwiÄ™k"
  example="Ich liebe dich = [ich li-be dich] - 'u' jak umlaut!"
/>

### Jak wymawiaÄ‡ umlauty

| Umlaut | Jak wymawiaÄ‡ | PrzykÅ‚ad |
|--------|--------------|----------|
| **a** | ZaokrÄ…gl usta na "o", powiedz "e" | M**a**dchen (dziewczynka) |
| **o** | ZaokrÄ…gl usta na "o", powiedz "e" | sch**o**n (piÄ™kny) |
| **u** | ZaokrÄ…gl usta na "u", powiedz "i" | f**u**r (dla) |

**Ä†wiczenie:** Powiedz "ee" (jak w "lewy"), zaokrÄ…glajÄ…c usta - to "o"!

## SpÃ³Å‚gÅ‚oski - rÃ³Å¼nice od polskiego

### CH - dwa dÅºwiÄ™ki!

<VocabCard
  word="ich vs ach"
  translation="ja vs ach"
  pronunciation="ich (miÄ™kkie) vs ach (twarde)"
  example="Dwa rÃ³Å¼ne dÅºwiÄ™ki 'ch' w niemieckim!"
/>

| Po samogÅ‚osce | DÅºwiÄ™k | PrzykÅ‚ad |
|---------------|--------|----------|
| **e, i, a, o, u** | MiÄ™kkie "ch" (jak delikatne "h") | i**ch**, ni**ch**t |
| **a, o, u, au** | Twarde "ch" (jak polskie "ch") | a**ch**, Bu**ch** |

### SCH - jak polskie "sz"

| Kombinacja | Wymowa | PrzykÅ‚ad |
|------------|--------|----------|
| **sch** | jak "sz" | **Sch**atz, **sch**on |
| **sp** (na poczÄ…tku) | jak "szp" | **sp**rechen |
| **st** (na poczÄ…tku) | jak "szt" | **st**ehen |

<CultureTip title="SP i ST na poczÄ…tku sÅ‚owa" flag="ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª">
"Sport" = "szport", "Stuhl" = "sztul"! Na poczÄ…tku sÅ‚owa "s" przed "p" i "t" brzmi jak "sz".
</CultureTip>

### W - jak polskie "w" (ale dÅºwiÄ™czne "f")

<VocabCard
  word="Wasser"
  translation="woda"
  pronunciation="wa-ser (nie 'Å‚aser'!)"
  example="Was? Wie? Wo? Wann? Warum?"
/>

| Litera | Niemiecka wymowa | PrzykÅ‚ad |
|--------|-----------------|----------|
| **w** | jak polskie "w" | **W**asser |
| **v** | jak "f" (lub "w" w sÅ‚owach obcych) | **V**ater = fater |
| **f** | jak "f" | **F**rau |

### R - gardÅ‚owe

Niemieckie "R" jest gardÅ‚owe (jak francuskie), szczegÃ³lnie na poczÄ…tku i w Å›rodku sÅ‚owa:

<VocabCard
  word="rot, Frau, Bruder"
  translation="czerwony, kobieta, brat"
  pronunciation="rot, frau, bru-der (R gardÅ‚owe)"
  example="R na koÅ„cu sÅ‚owa czÄ™sto niesÅ‚yszalne: Vater = fata"
/>

**Na koÅ„cu sÅ‚owa "R" jest czÄ™sto zredukowane lub niesÅ‚yszalne:**
- Vater [fa-ta]
- Mutter [mu-ta]
- Wasser [wa-sa]

## Kombinacje samogÅ‚oskowe

| Kombinacja | Wymowa | PrzykÅ‚ad |
|------------|--------|----------|
| **ei** | jak "aj" | m**ei**n = majn |
| **ie** | jak dÅ‚ugie "i" | L**ie**be = li-be |
| **eu/au** | jak "oj" | h**eu**te = hoj-te |
| **au** | jak "au" | H**au**s = haus |

<VocabCard
  word="Ich liebe dich"
  translation="Kocham ciÄ™"
  pronunciation="ich li-be dich"

/>

## KoÅ„cÃ³wki sÅ‚Ã³w

### -IG na koÅ„cu = "ich"

| SÅ‚owo | Wymowa | Znaczenie |
|-------|--------|-----------|
| wichtig | wich-tich | waÅ¼ny |
| richtig | rich-tich | prawidÅ‚owy |

### -ER na koÅ„cu = "a" (zredukowane)

| SÅ‚owo | Wymowa | Znaczenie |

| Vater | fa-ta | ojciec |
| Mutter | mu-ta | matka |
| aber | a-ba | ale |

### KoÅ„cowe -E jest wymawiane!

| SÅ‚owo | Wymowa | Znaczenie |
|-------|--------|-----------|
| liebe | li-be | kocham |
| heute | hoj-te | dzisiaj |

## Akcent w sÅ‚owach

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Zwykle na pierwszej sylabie!"
  translation="Usually on the first syllable!"
  pronunciation="niemiecki akcent jest regularny"
  context="Prosta zasada z wyjÄ…tkami"
/>

**Zasada gÅ‚Ã³wna:** Akcent pada na PIERWSZÄ„ sylabÄ™

| SÅ‚owo | Akcent | Wymowa |
|-------|--------|--------|
| **Lie**be | pierwsza | LI-be |
| **Mor**gen | pierwsza | MOR-gen |
| **Ar**beit | pierwsza | AR-bajt |

**WyjÄ…tki:** Przedrostki nieakcentowane (be-, ge-, ver-, ent-)
- ver**STE**hen
- be**KOM**men

## Ä†wiczenia dla par

### Ä†wiczenie 1: Umlauty
Powtarzajcie na przemian:
- schon (juÅ¼) vs schon (piÄ™kny)
- schwul (parny) vs schwul (gejowski - ostroÅ¼nie!)
- Mutter vs Mutter

### Ä†wiczenie 2: CH miÄ™kkie vs twarde
- ich, mich, nicht, richtig (miÄ™kkie)

### Ä†wiczenie 3: EI vs IE
- mein (mÃ³j) vs Biene (pszczoÅ‚a)
- Wein (wino) vs Wien (WiedeÅ„)
- sein (byÄ‡) vs siÄ™ (ona)

### Ä†wiczenie 4: Romantyczne frazy
Ä†wiczcie wymowÄ™:
- "Ich liebe dich" [ich li-be dich]
- "Du bist wunderschon" [du bist wun-der-szen]

## NajczÄ™stsze bÅ‚Ä™dy PolakÃ³w

| BÅ‚Ä…d | PrzykÅ‚ad | Poprawnie |
|------|----------|-----------|
| "W" jak "Å‚" | "Å‚aser" | "waser" (Wasser) |
| Brak umlautÃ³w | "fur" jak "fur" | "fur" z zaokrÄ…gleniem |
| CH zawsze twarde | "ich" jak "ych" | miÄ™kkie "ich" |

## Podsumowanie

Niemiecka wymowa jest regularna i logiczna! Kluczowe elementy:
1. Umlauty (a, o, u) - zaokrÄ…glaj usta!
2. CH ma dwa dÅºwiÄ™ki (miÄ™kkie i twarde)
3. EI = "aj", IE = dÅ‚ugie "i"
4. Akcent zwykle na pierwszej sylabie
5. R gardÅ‚owe, nie polskie
